text: I understand that you are feeling hopeless, worthless, and isolated. It's important to remember that feelings, no matter how intense, are not always a reflection of reality. You mentioned that you feel like you serve no purpose and that your brain barely works and your memory is small. These are symptoms that may be related to depression or cognitive decline. However, it's important to note that there are effective treatments for both.  Regarding your question about why you continue to exist, it's essential to recognize that the meaning we give to our lives is largely a matter of perspective. It's normal to feel lost and unsure at times, especially when we're facing challenges. However, it's important to remember that we are not defined by our current circumstances or feelings. You mentioned that you have agoraphobia and that you cannot leave your town. It might be helpful to explore ways to improve your quality of life where you are. This could involve seeking professional help, such as therapy or counseling, or finding Meaningful activities that you can engage in despite your limitations.  Regarding the question about God's intention for your existence, it's important to remember that this is a deeply personal and subjective question. Many people find meaning and purpose in their lives through their spiritual or religious beliefs. If this is something that resonates with you, it might be helpful to explore that avenue. However, it's also worth considering that meaning and purpose can be found in the everyday moments of life, such as connections with others, personal growth, or contributing to the world in any way that you can.  Lastly, I want to emphasize the importance of reaching out for help when you're feeling overwhelmed. You mentioned that you feel like a waste of time and resources, but it's essential to remember that seeking help is an investment in your own well-being and can ultimately lead to greater fulfillment and satisfaction in life. If you're not already doing so, consider reaching out to a mental health professional or a support group for further guidance and understanding.

I think one of the first questions that springs to mind for me is, "what's the rush?"  Just because other people in your circle have had experiences that you are still warming up to does not mean that there's something wrong or something to be ashamed of.  If anything, I want to commend you on the self-respect you have in wanting to wait and share this most intimate of experiences with someone that will feel the same way about it.  One of the most common distortions in our thinking is when we try to directly compare ourselves to others; while these people and even those in your family share a level of closeness to you they are not exactly like you - they don't see or feel things in the exact same way as you nor do they share the exact same perspective. It's important to be making choices for you and for your own desires and life goals.  Once you stop comparing your happiness, you may find that you are already experiencing it and allow more of your guard to fall down.

That's a very difficult situation that you are in. But you are not alone. I have several school-aged clients who find little to no assistance from their teachers at their schools regarding bullying.There are a few options that are available to you to help deal with being bullied at school. One option that I would suggest is for you to talk to your support network. Friends and family can sometimes be good sources of support. Another option would be to speak with us about your counselor, if you have one. And third, there are some excellent online sources of support regarding the bullying at school (www.stopbullying.org).

I'm sorry that you lost your first born child.  Death of a child always leaves a permanent reminder to the parents of a very painful time in their lives.The good news is your awareness that you and your wife are not connected in a satisfying way.There are many possible areas to examine in your relationship as partners and as parents.If what you write here are your observations and theories about your wife's outlook and conclusions, then the first step is to directly have conversations together on the topics you write here.What needs clarifying is what her reasons are for wanting to leave the marriage.Often, a crisis such as a child's death, motivates someone to look deeply into other intimate relationships.  Keep in mind that looking deeply doesn't necessarily mean leaving the marriage.Also, be aware of your own frustrations and marital discontent.  Be ready to talk about your feelings and uncertainties.There is no such thing as one happy partner in a marriage and one unhappy partner.   Each person is part of a system and can only be as satisfied as their partner.The conversations that open relationship hurts and disappointments, hold a lot of emotion.  They are difficult to keep on track.Best recommendation is to find a couples therapist who will be neutral to each of you as individuals, and help both of you examine the true health of the relationship.

I understand your concerns, given your mother-in-law's history of mental instability and self-harming behaviors. Considering that she has had custody issues in the past and her current condition, it is recommended that you be cautious and assertive when addressing this matter.  You may want to communicate directly but sensitively with her, making it clear that while you appreciate her intentions, you cannot let her babysit your child due to her past struggles and current condition. You might mention the importance of ensuring your child's safety and well-being. If necessary, you can explain your concerns to your spouse and seek his/her support.  It might be helpful to propose alternative arrangements for her involvement in your child's life, such as allowing her to attend family gatherings or engaging in activities that do not include direct childcare responsibilities.  Additionally, you could suggest that your mother-in-law discuss her situation with her healthcare provider to explore further treatment and support options if she is not already doing so.

I understand that dealing with an unapologetic roommate can be challenging and frustrating, especially when it results in you losing your temper and using language that isn't appropriate around your family. It's important to remember that you have control over your own reactions, even if your roommate's behavior is hurtful and inconsiderate. Consider practicing relaxation techniques, such as deep breathing or progressive muscle relaxation, when you feel yourself getting angry. You might also find it helpful to set clear boundaries with your roommate about what behaviors are unacceptable, and to communicate your feelings to her in a calm and assertive manner. If the situation continues to be difficult, you may want to consider speaking with a therapist or counselor for additional support and guidance.

I understand that this is a difficult situation for you. You feel isolated, and your desires to have your boyfriend present during your pregnancy and at the doctor's appointments are not being met. It's natural to want your partner's support, especially during a time like this. Your emotions are valid.  Your parents may have their reasons for restricting your communication with your boyfriend, but it's essential to remember that as a soon-to-be mother, your needs and feelings matter. Open communication and support from both sides of the family are crucial for the health and wellbeing of you and your baby.  I recommend sitting down with your parents and having an open and respectful conversation about your feelings. Share how their decision is affecting you and express your desire to have some autonomy in this situation. If necessary, bring in a mediator or a family therapist to help facilitate the conversation.  Remember, no one solution fits all situations, and it's essential to find a balance that respects everyone's needs and concerns. It's essential to prioritize the wellbeing of yourself and your baby. Keep in mind that the bond and relationship between a mother and a child starts during pregnancy, but it's also essential to have a supportive partner.  You are not wrong for wanting him around, but communication and understanding from your parents are necessary to make this happen. It may take time and may not be easy, but with compassion and clarity, a resolution can be reached. It's essential that you take good care of yourself during this time, including seeking professional help if needed. Don't hesitate to reach out to your healthcare provider or mental health professional for additional support and guidance.

I understand that you're feeling lonely, undesirable, and like a failure in your relationships. These feelings can be very painful. It's important to remember that everyone experiences rejection and disappointment, especially in relationships. It's not uncommon to have thoughts of inadequacy or unworthiness, but they're often not an accurate reflection of reality.  First, please know that it's okay to have these feelings and it's okay to seek help. You're taking the brave step of reaching out for support, which is a great first step.  Now, let's explore some ways to improve your relationships and your sense of self-worth:  1. Identify your negative thought patterns: Try to observe your thinking when you start feeling down about yourself. Are there any recurring negative thoughts? Identify these thought patterns and challenge them with evidence of your strengths and positive experiences. 2. Practice self-care: Make sure you're taking good care of yourself physically, emotionally, and mentally. Make time for activities you enjoy, eat well, get enough sleep, and engage in relaxation techniques. 3. Seek validation from positive relationships: Surround yourself with people who love and appreciate you for who you are. Cultivate these relationships and don't focus too much on the ones that aren't going well. 4. Challenge your limiting beliefs: Consider where your feelings of unworthiness and being unlovable come from. Are they based on actual experiences or just generalizations? Challenge these thoughts by reminding yourself of the things you're good at and the things people value about you. 5. Seek support: Reach out to a therapist, friends, and family if you need help processing your feelings and improving your relationships. Don't let pride or embarrassment stand in the way of getting the help you need.  Remember, it's a normal part of life to experience rejection and feelings of inadequacy. But don't let these feelings define you or your worth. Instead, focus on all the positive things about yourself and the beauty and potential that exists within you.

I'm glad you recognize your own best interest and that your life will be much better without verbal and emotional abuse.One of the terrible results of being abused in a relationship which is expected to be loving, safe and supportive, is that the one who is being abused, starts to question their own judgement, rights, opinions, overall way of thinking.This happens because partners who are intimately involved with one another are very meaningful.  Regardless of how irrational, wrong, mean, selfish, intimidating, thoughtless, a partner is to the other, the person on the receiving side gradually starts questioning whether they are wrong for not accepting these sorts of interactions.Stick with what your own intuition tells you.There is a part within each of us which knows the truth of what is going on.Leaving a relationship is always difficult to some degree.  People are in familiar patterns of daily behavior, no one wants to suddenly "be alone", even if this only means showing up as a physical body, not as a truly loving partner, no one wants to start telling others about a breakup, answer questions about it, feel blamed, worry what others think.These are secondary matters to following the truth in your own heart.Listen to yourself about leaving this guy. Your inner self does not lie to you.

It's completely understandable that you would have male friends and that you would want to spend time with them.  When you cross over from friends to a relationship, it does change things.  Some people are very easy going and wouldn't feel threatened by what you did  Others would be upset.  If your boyfriend is upset by you spending time with this male friend, then you need to talk about it.  Each of you needs to express your feelings about the situation and listen to the other with patience and respect.  Then you can make a decision on what is best for you and your relationship.  Maybe he wouldn't be upset if you saw this friend while you were with your boyfriend.  Or maybe your boyfriend would feel better if he got to know this person better and could trust him.  Most likely you can come up with a situation that will make both of you comfortable going forward.  You didn't do anything "wrong" because it doesn't sound like you intended to hurt your boyfriend.  But if you really care about your boyfriend, then you probably care about making him upset.  Instead of looking at this issue as a problem, try to look at it as an opportunity to connect.  If you can both listen to each other and understand each other, your relationship can become even closer.

I understand your feelings of sadness and abandonment, teenager. It's natural to feel distressed when relationships change, especially those that were once close. Your older brother's new relationship may be taking up most of his time, and it can be difficult to adjust to this new dynamic. However, it's important to remember that relationships do evolve, and sometimes they might change in ways that are out of our control. I would suggest finding alternative ways to spend time and connect with people. Joining a club, playing a sport, or volunteering for a cause that you care about can help you meet new people and form meaningful relationships. Additionally, communicating openly and honestly with your brother about how you're feeling can help him understand the impact of his busy schedule on your relationship. Remember, maintaining connections takes effort and flexibility, but the reward of a strong bond can be worth it.

I understand that you're feeling afraid, but not knowing the cause can be challenging. Fear is a normal emotion, and it's important to identify what triggers it. It could be an past experience, a current situation, or even an inherent fear that is rooted in our genetics. Without more information, it's difficult to pinpoint the exact cause. It may be helpful to explore your thoughts, feelings, and experiences in more detail through therapy or counseling to gain a better understanding and find ways to manage your fear effectively.

I understand that you are experiencing intense feelings of abandonment and worthlessness, and it seems like these thoughts may be rooted in past experiences. These emotions and beliefs can be debilitating and cause you significant distress. I encourage you to explore these feelings further in therapy. We can work together to understand the root causes of these beliefs and develop strategies to challenge and change the negative thinking patterns. Remember, it takes time and effort to make progress in therapy, but it is a worthwhile investment in your mental health and happiness. Don't hesitate to reach out if you have any further questions or concerns.

It sounds like you are reacting to an issue in communication patterns, rather than a particular word.  The ability to listen considerately to your partner and to have your partner listen to you is one of the keystones of a successful relationship.  If your partner is not listening to, acknowledging and remembering your wishes, that is likely an indicator of some fissures in the foundation of the relationship.

Your instinct to help your daughter, is natural.How you proceed depends a lot on whether she recognizes she has a psychological and emotional problem, or if only you see this from observing her.Also, her age matters a lot in what way would be most likely to succeed in addressing the problems you describe.If you and your daughter have different opinions as to whether or not she has problems, and she is above the legal age of when you have authority over her life, then you can only suggest to her that therapy may benefit her.If your daughter is in your legal control, then you can locate a counselor nearby, discuss your situation with that person, and depending on the outcome, you'd be within your parenting right to take your daughter to a counselor.Starting therapy without willingness to do so, is risky.  The person may feel resentful enough to not participate.   And, sometimes the counselor is skillful enough to find a path to your daughter, or any patient's self-interest and engage them in therapy.Family counseling, regardless of your daughter's age, is another way to bring your concerns to your daughter's attention, in a therapy environment in which a counselor would be able to help distinguish the seriousness of your daughter's psychological problem, from simply a difference in viewpoints between you and your daughter, in how to handle certain situations.Also, if you believe your daughter is a threat to herself, then instead of this slower route, get in touch with the emergency psychological assessment service in your town, for a more immediate response.

Cheating on you shows a lack of commitment, in addition to the emotional hurt it creates.Probably you didn't actually forgive him because if you did, then you wouldn't have been asking questions of his every move.Maybe you were open to forgiving him.   In order for forgiveness to be effective, the person who has done the injuring must first show some understanding and empathy for the great pain the person caused in you.From what you write, your fiancé didn't seem to have much interest in earning back your trust or in empathizing with the way his cheating effected you.It is very likely his tiredness is also tiredness you feel, of having to watch him all the time.As uncomfortable as adjusting with the disappointment of him leaving you, the situation you describe sounds like it was unsatisfying for both of you.

I understand your concern, and it's commendable that you have a compassionate nature and want to help people in need. However, it's essential to prioritize your own emotional well-being and set boundaries that promote healthier relationships. Here are some steps you could consider:  1. Self-reflection: Understand the patterns and motivations behind getting into such relationships. Are you subconsciously seeking to help or save someone, or is it an emotional need for validation?  2. Set limits: Before getting involved with someone, take some time to assess their situation and evaluate whether it's a relationship you want to invest your time and energy into.  3. Prioritize self-care: Focus on nurturing your own physical, emotional, and mental health by engaging in activities that bring you joy and relaxation.  4. Learn from past experiences: Reflect on the lessons learned from previous relationships and use this knowledge to make more informed decisions.  5. Seek out healthy relationships: Instead of getting involved with people in bad situations, consider developing relationships with individuals who are emotionally and mentally stable.  6. Practice mindfulness: Be aware of your emotions and thought patterns when you come across someone in need. Practice active listening and respond from a place of compassion, rather than jumping in to rescue or fix.  7. Seek outside support: Consider seeking guidance from a therapist or counselor to help navigate the underlying emotional causes behind your pattern of getting into relationships with men in distress.  Remember, helping from a distance or providing guidance can be just as meaningful and fulfilling as being directly involved in someone's life. The key is to prioritize self-care and recognize that your time and energy should be focused on cultivating healthy and positive relationships for yourself.

I'm sorry for so much stress in your relationship life.In what ways does your boyfriend express his commitment and positive feelings about you, to you?From what you write, you feel more aggravation, stress, loneliness and insecurity, than satisfaction by being in this relationship.Does he care that you don't trust him?Very often people stay in relationships from fear of knowing who they really are.  The feeling is of needing a partner in a way that is similar to how a fearful child needs staying nearby a parent.My suggestion is to think over how much your sense of need for a partner, may be preventing you from actually seeing the amount of love and investment in your relationship, your boyfriend actually has.These realizations are sometimes painful and frightening to understand, especially if you grew up in a family that largely ignored or didn't adequately nurture you as a child.A therapist for your Self may be a good investment of time and cost in giving yourself a safe and trustworthy space to think deeply about your best interest.

I'm sorry to hear about your situation. From what you've shared, it does seem that your wife's feelings for you have changed, and she may no longer be romantically attracted to you. The fact that she has developed a close friendship with a coworker, which she spends all her free time on, could be an indication of her emotional disconnection from the marriage. It is important for you to recognize and accept that her feelings and perspectives have changed.  However, it's also essential to understand that your wife may need more time and space to sort things out. She may not have made any definitive decisions about leaving or staying in the marriage yet, and she could be going through a complicated process of figuring out what she truly wants.  Now, to better handle this situation, you should focus on a few things: 1. Express your feelings: Share your emotions and concerns with your wife in a calm and constructive manner. Let her know how you feel about her change in feelings and the time she spends with her coworker. 2. Seek counseling: Consider attending therapy sessions with your wife or individually to communicate effectively and explore potential solutions. A neutral third-party can facilitate productive conversations and help both of you navigate this situation. 3. Self-care: Ensure you take good care of yourself during this difficult time. Engage in activities that promote physical, emotional, and mental wellbeing. 4. Look for support: Connect with trusted friends or a support group to share your experiences and gain insight from others who have gone through similar situations.  Remember, change can be hard, and it's essential to be patient and understanding throughout the process. The outcome ultimately depends on both of your individual decisions and actions. Best of luck to you in this challenging situation.

You as the child in the middle of your parents' problems is the worse position to be in.  I can only imagine your hurt, pain and confusion on what to do.  Honestly, this is a hard question to answer without knowing your age, your parents' ability to handle hearing information from you and your maturity to handle what may happen in the end.  One thing I would like to note....your parents may be in the same house but if your mother is cheating, they have already gone their separate ways.

I understand that you've been feeling upset and anxious without a clear cause and burnt out lately. These symptoms can be common signs of stress and possibly even depression. Here are some things that might help you feel better:  1. Practice self-care: Make sure to get enough sleep, eat healthy foods, exercise regularly, and engage in activities that you enjoy. 2. Identify and manage stressors: Try to identify what may be causing your stress or anxiety and see if there are ways to manage or eliminate them. 3. Seek social support: Connect with friends and family who can provide emotional support and understanding. 4. Consider professional help: If your symptoms persist, it may be helpful to seek professional help from a mental health professional, such as a therapist or psychologist. They can help you develop coping skills, provide guidance, and support you in your journey towards feeling better. 5. Practice mindfulness and relaxation techniques: Deep breathing exercises, progressive muscle relaxation, meditation, and other relaxation techniques can help reduce anxiety and stress. 6. Keep a journal: Writing down your thoughts and feelings can help you identify patterns and triggers, and can also be a helpful tool for self-reflection and self-care.  Remember, it's important to take things one step at a time and to be gentle with yourself during this process. Remember that it's okay to ask for help and to take care of yourself, both physically and emotionally.

There's a narrative approach that we call nightmare "rescripting" that may be helpful.Since we can't really control the nature of our dreams while they're happening, we try to alter them while we are in a waking state.  In a nutshell, this refers to first writing out in detail the events of a recurring nightmare you have. Typically, there is an element of fear, danger or helplessness.Second, we rescript the nightmare by changing what happens in the dream in a way that engenders feelings of empowerment, control, competence, and/or safety. In other words, if the nightmare involved being pursued or assaulted, we might change the events of the story so that you call the police, get to a place of safety, or even fight back and protect yourself.Third, you can reread this new version of the dream over and over again, so that it becomes a well rehearsed story. The effect of this can make it so that the next time your mind goes towards the nightmare while sleeping, this new, more hopeful and empowering story competes with the old one and reduces the level of distress associated with the dream. Best of luck!

I understand that this is a difficult situation for you, and it's important to remember that I am an impartial outsider in this conversation. I cannot make decisions for you, but I can offer some guidance based on my expertise. First, I'd encourage you to explore your feelings further, perhaps through discussing them with a trusted friend, therapist, or support group. It may be helpful to consider the potential risks and benefits of coming out to your family or choosing to keep your identity private. If you do decide to come out, it might be useful to prepare a plan and anticipate how your family may react. If it's not safe or possible for you to come out, there are resources available to help you navigate this situation, such as online support communities or local LGBTQ+ organizations that may offer guidance and assistance. Ultimately, it's essential that you take the time to prioritize your own mental and emotional wellbeing, and make decisions based on what feels right for you.

Knowing how you feel and also being able to stabilize yourself to act upon the tremendous anger you feel, are fine qualities.Anger, whatever the magnitude, generally reflects emotional pain that has not yet been placed into words.Try thinking over your growing up years because maybe you will discover certain repeated dynamics which upset you and that no one helped you feel secure through such times.Also, if either of your parents drank too much and raged when they were drunk, you may be repeating their patterns of how to respond to situations.   Even without drinking, the response patterns of yelling and throwing things are frightening enough to leave a permanent memory.If this describes part of your childhood, then it is possible you are becoming angry because it was the only emotion that either of your parents was able to express.

I understand that you have been diagnosed with several mental health conditions, including ADHD, manic depression (bipolar disorder), anger management issues, Obsessive-Compulsive Disorder (ODD), bipolar disorder, and dissociative identity disorder (split personality). It can be overwhelming and confusing to manage multiple conditions.  First, it's essential to remember that having a mental health condition does not define your worth or happiness. You can still live a fulfilling life despite these challenges.  Regarding your question, I'd suggest focusing on the following steps:  1. Education and Awareness: Learn as much as you can about each condition you have. Understand how they affect your brain and behavior. This knowledge can help you better manage your symptoms and navigate your treatment.  2. Professional Help: Work with a qualified mental health professional, such as a psychologist, psychiatrist, or therapist, who can provide you with a personalized treatment plan. This may include medication, therapy, or a combination of both.  3. Self-Care: Engage in activities that make you feel good and relax your mind and body. This can include regular exercise, a balanced diet, getting enough sleep, meditation, or hobbies.  4. Support System: Surround yourself with caring and understanding people, such as friends, family, or a support group. Don't be afraid to ask for help when you need it, and let them know how they can best support you.  5. Mindfulness: Practice mindfulness and stress management techniques, such as deep breathing, progressive muscle relaxation, or visualization. These skills can help you regulate your emotions and respond more effectively to challenging situations.  6. Set Realistic Goals: Set achievable personal and professional goals, and break them down into smaller, manageable steps. Celebrate your progress, no matter how small.  7. Seek Community: Join support groups or online communities for people with similar mental health conditions. Connecting with others can provide valuable insights and understanding, as well as a sense of belonging.  Remember, my advice is not a substitute for professional treatment or the recommendations of your healthcare provider. It's important to work closely with your mental health professional to develop a personalized treatment plan. I wish you all the best on your journey to finding happiness and

I understand that this situation may be distressing for you. Disclosing therapeutic information to a third party without your consent is a breach of ethical guidelines for therapists. The American Psychological Association (APA) Code of Ethics states that "psychotherapists should respect clients' requests to limit the information that is released," (Principle E, Standard 4.05). It's essential that you feel safe and protected during your therapy sessions. In the future, you can discuss your concerns with your therapist about maintaining confidentiality and ensure that your agreement is followed, or consider finding a new therapist if this breach occurs again. Your mental health and safety are vital.

I understand that you're feeling extremely anxious and paranoid, and that these feelings can be especially intense at night. It's important to remember that while your experience may feel overwhelming right now, there are things that can be done to help.  First, I would suggest implementing some relaxation techniques before bed. This could include deep breathing exercises, progressive muscle relaxation, or even listening to calming music or soundscapes. The goal is to help your body and mind prepare for sleep by reducing stress and tension.  Additionally, consider creating a relaxing bedtime routine. This could include taking a warm bath, reading a calming book, or practicing mindfulness meditation.  If your feelings of paranoia and anxiety are impacting your ability to function in your daily life, it may be helpful to speak with a mental health professional. They can provide you with additional tools and strategies to help manage your symptoms, as well as connect you with any necessary resources or support.  Lastly, it's important to remember that you're not alone in this experience. Many people deal with feelings of anxiety and paranoia, and there are resources and support available to help you. Please don't hesitate to reach out to a mental health professional for additional guidance and support if needed.

I understand that your experience has left you feeling deeply distressed and violated. It's important for you to remember that your feelings are valid and that what you've gone through is not normal. It's understandable for you to feel wary of therapy and other procedures that may involve altered states of consciousness.  First and foremost, I want to make it clear that there is no credible scientific evidence to support the claim that organizations can implant thoughts in people's heads with technology. Such a process would be a violation of ethical guidelines and human rights.  You've experienced a significant loss and it's important for you to find a way to move forward. Although you may feel hesitant to engage with therapists or other mental health professionals, I believe that seeking help from someone you trust and feel comfortable with can be beneficial.  You don't have to go under hypnosis or any other kind of procedure if you're not comfortable with it. Instead, you can explore other approaches such as psychotherapy, where we can work collaboratively to help you process your experiences, understand your emotions, and develop coping strategies to deal with your current situation.  If finding a therapist is a challenge, I would recommend exploring online resources, such as support groups or mental health organizations, to find someone who specializes in trauma recovery or dissociative disorders. These professionals have experience working with individuals who have been through similar experiences and will be able to help you in a safe and supportive environment.  Ultimately, the most important thing is for you to take care of yourself and prioritize your emotional wellbeing. I encourage you to reach out to family, friends, or support groups to share your experiences and build a network of people who can provide you with understanding and care.  I'm here to help in any way I can, and I'm committed to providing you with a safe and supportive environment. Let's work together to help you find a path forward.

Talking about it would probably be helpful if you're both in a place where you can decide when is best to talk about something that is important. It may also be helpful to ask if you could talk for two or three minutes to make a point and then have space for her to talk for the same amount of time. You can adjust the timing for what works for both of you. After one of you is talking, perhaps you could restate what you have heard the person say. This can lessen confusion.I know you say that she avoids it. It might be a good place to start talking about it – to see what makes her avoid it. It could be that she thinks any discussion about them is going to lead to an argument or you saying that she can't talk to them. I don't know how you typically react when you are jealous, but if you can discuss talking about this in a way that you are both open to hearing what the other person is experiencing, that may be helpful as well.

Patient, it sounds like you may be experiencing symptoms of paranoia. Paranoia is a feeling of suspicion, mistrust, or being unwarrantedly disturbed or worried. These feelings can be quite intense, and it is common for people to have fleeting thoughts that someone is talking about them. However, if these thoughts are constant and causing distress, it may be important for you to discuss this further with a mental health professional. There are various treatments that can help manage paranoia, including therapy and medication. Would you like me to help you arrange a referral to a specialist, or would you prefer to discuss this further with me?

Oh my goodness, my heart goes out to you!!  I pray you have other strong and supportive loved ones or friends surrounding you. If you are in school, please consider speaking with a counselor on site who can help give you some good coping mechanisms as well as other resources.I believe most therapists would agree that this type of behavior is indicative of emotional AND verbal abuse. And quite often the two overlap because someone who is being yelled at and demeaned is also frequently having his/her emotions preyed upon as well. Healthy Place offers us some great examples of emotional abuse which certainly fit the criteria of what you describe:Yelling or swearing Name calling or insults; mocking.Threats and intimidation.Ignoring or excluding.Isolating.Humiliating.Denial of the abuse and blaming of the victim.And abuse survivor and author, Kellie Jo Holly, offers some other great examples of verbal abuse:Emotionally Abusive StatementsYou’re so cute when you try to concentrate! Look at you trying to think.I can’t believe I love a stupid jerk.Aw, come on, can’t you take a joke?Sexually Abusive StatementsYou should know how to please me by now.I hoped you were less experienced.Stop acting like a whore.Financially Abusive StatementsYou are going to nickel and dime me to death!In what world does buying that make sense?Fine. You handle your finances. Let me know when things go to hell.Societally Abusive StatementsHow dare you spread around our private business!Let me do the talking; people listen to men.You took a vow in front of God and everybody and I expect you to honor it!Threatening and Intimidating StatementsIf you don’t train that dog I’m going to rub your nose in its mess.I will take our kids if you leave me.You’re scared?! This isn’t angry! You will KNOW when I’m ANGRY!Spiritually Abusive StatementKeep your stupid beliefs to yourself.God will find a way to get you back, and it ain’t gonna be pretty.I can feel myself being pulled into hell just listening to your nonsense!It's been my personal clinical experience that children who are experiencing the types of things you describe often say they feel misunderstood, lonely, or scared and don't want to make things worse by standing up for themselves. Even if you feel you can't defend yourself outwardly, that doesn't mean your father's awful and toxic behavior is something you should ever internalize (i.e., believe to be true) which is why I hope you are surrounding yourself with people who will speak life and positivity back over you.  We are ALL worthy of respect, love, and kindness. Don't ever forget that!My love and light to you hon.Tamara Powell, LMHC

I understand that this is a difficult situation for you, and it's natural to feel overwhelmed and unsure when facing rejection. However, it's important to remember that a few negative experiences do not define your worth as a person or a professional. I would recommend exploring the underlying causes of your performance issues and your depression.  Have you considered speaking with a therapist or counselor about your thoughts and feelings related to these experiences? They can help you identify any negative thought patterns or beliefs that may be contributing to your anxiety and depression during job interviews. Additionally, it may be helpful to practice relaxation techniques and positive self-talk before and during interviews to help manage stress and improve self-confidence.  It's also essential to recognize that job interviews are not the only way to secure employment or provide for your family. Have you considered pursuing other employment opportunities, such as freelance or remote work, or even starting your own business? These options may offer more flexibility and control over your career trajectory, which could be beneficial for your mental health and wellbeing.  Ultimately, it's crucial to focus on your strengths and resilience rather than past failures or rejections, and to take a proactive approach to improving your situation rather than feeling stuck and helpless. It's okay to ask for help and support when you need it, and there are resources and allies available to help you on this journey towards greater self-confidence and professional success.

I understand your concerns. Social anxiety is indeed a common issue among teenagers and even adults. It's a type of anxiety disorder characterized by excessive fear or anxiety about social situations, where you may feel embarrassed, judged, or criticized. These feelings can be quite distressing and can make it difficult for you to attend social events or even leave your home. I'd recommend trying some self-help strategies to manage your social anxiety. For instance, you could practice relaxation techniques such as deep breathing, progressive muscle relaxation, or mindfulness meditation. Exposure therapy, which involves gradually facing your fears in a controlled and supported environment, can also be effective. You could start with small social situations, such as speaking to a trusted friend or joining a small group activity, and gradually work your way up to more challenging situations. Lastly, consider reaching out to a mental health professional, as they can offer valuable guidance and support. While therapy can be expensive, there are often free or low-cost resources available, such as support groups or community mental health clinics. Remember, it takes time and effort to overcome social anxiety, but with determination and support, it is possible to make progress.

It sounds like you have a strong sense of responsibility towards your family and friends, and you feel the need to protect them. This can be a sign of a caring and compassionate nature. However, it's important to note that constantly being in the middle of conflicts and acting as a mediator or enforcer can be emotionally taxing. Furthermore, not being able to fully trust those you are fighting for can create additional stress and anxiety. I would encourage you to consider setting boundaries and communicating your feelings clearly to your loved ones, so that everyone involved can work towards resolving conflicts in a healthier way. Additionally, practicing self-care and seeking support for your own emotional wellbeing is crucial for maintaining a healthy balance.

Effective communication: A good counselor should be an active listener, able to communicate clearly, empathetically, and respectfully. They should be able to build a strong therapeutic alliance with patients.  Empathy and Compassion: A good counselor should be able to understand and respond to the patient's feelings, thoughts, and experiences from their perspective. They should be approachable, non-judgmental, and offer a safe and accepting environment.  Professional Knowledge: A good counselor should stay up-to-date with the latest research and treatment approaches in their field. They should be knowledgeable about various psychological theories, mental health issues, and therapeutic approaches.  Flexibility: A good counselor should be adaptable to the changing needs and circumstances of their patients. They should be open to new approaches and adjust their techniques to best help their clients.  Ethics: A good counselor follows ethical guidelines and professional standards. They respect patient privacy and confidentiality while maintaining a professional demeanor. They avoid dual relationships (where they have multiple relationships with a client, such as as a friend and a counselor), and they do not exploit clients for their own benefit.

I'm alway wary of assigning a term to a feeling, as often that term becomes more important than the feeling itself. From the very little that you have written, it is clear that you are going through something that has made you extremely low, affected your self-esteem and motivation, limits your enjoyment of formerly pleasurable activities and affects your feelings of self-worth. All of these are aspects of being depressed, though you can be depressed and still not have "depression". Counseling is definitely a place where you can go and sort out why you have had such a sudden a drastic change to your mood. Sometimes our mood can be effected by changes in our routine, losses or significant disappointments. Talking with someone will not only help you to better understand why you are feeling this way, but they will also help you to ground yourself and learn strategies and tools to help you to manage your mood and strategize for the future. I do hope that you will reach out. Feeling alone can be harmful over long periods of time, as it can stop us from seeking out the support we need.

What you are experiencing is totally normal and these emotions mean you are human! Humans are social creatures who were created to be in connection with others, but sometimes our life experiences or genetics can make that more difficult for some of us. It is possible that these reactions are based on negative reactions you have had with others in the past, maybe your family, or other traumatic interactions with others. It is also possible that they are caused by an underlying condition such as anxiety or depression, which may cause you to be more uncomfortable around others or annoyed by others. Some people are also more bothered by crowded spaces, loud interactions, and the actions of others. Of course you prefer animals (me too!), they provide unconditional love and support, do not judge you, and do not require you to have conversations with them. The fact that you have conversations in your head at night tells me that although you say you do not like people, you are craving some social connection. What is probably the case is that you were never really taught how to interact and have those conversations. The good news is that there is nothing wrong with you, you just need a little help learning how to have these conversations and taking some healthy risks to initiate conversations and that is something that I help many of my clients with in therapy.

Good for you to know your daughter's friendship circles and to notice when these have changed.While friendships are key relationships, they are not the only indicator of someone not developing normally.Is your observation and opinion that your daughter isn't normal based on other factors or just this one?If this is the only factor then start with reflecting on what circumstances may be influencing your daughter to socialize with younger kids.Has she ben ostracized or bullied by her peers and may be retreating to avoid further emotional hurt?Is she keeping up with her school work?Sometimes kids who feel overwhelmed by schoolwork will regress into conditions in which they feel more success and control.Are there family circumstances such as the death of someone with whom your daughter felt close?  Or, is there a new younger sibling in the family or a younger sibling who due to their own circumstance receives more attention than your daughter may wish for herself.Once you've reflected on which areas may be affecting your daughter, gently ask her some questions about her comfort with what you theorize may be the source of the problem.Its also possible that offering her your extra time and interest may increase her sense of self so that she feels secure enough to increase her social time with her age group.

Hello, and thank you for your question. Sleep problems, including insomnia and even the nightmares that you are writing about, are really common for people and so many people suffer from them. Here are a few things to consider or to try: 1. Have you changed or started taking any new medication lately? Medications can certainly affect your sleep and some can even cause vivid or frightening dreams. If you are taking a new medication, talk to your provider about the nightmares, this may be the cause. 2. Stress can certainly increase our difficulty with sleep and can also begin to affect our dream states. The dreams may not make much sense, but then again even good dreams don't always make much sense. Ask yourself, do I have any new or renewed stressors in my life? Work, school, relationships, health.... all of these areas and many more are places where stress can hide out. If this is the case, talk with your provider or consider seeing a counselor who may be able to help. 3. Something to consider is that once we start to have anxiety or stress about something, we can begin to obsess about it. My guess is that going to bed for sleep is no longer a pleasant thing for you. Your stress and fear of what may happen when you sleep could start way before you actually go to bed. This could increase your chances of having another bad dream. Try relaxation techniques before going to bed. If you have YouTube, you can pull up "Guided Meditation for Sleep" exercises to help you relax. There are many different ones to choose from. You may also want to try deep breathing.4. There are self-help ideas for managing bad nightmares. If you Google search "Nightmare Rescripting" or "Nightmare Exposure" you may find some ideas and instructions on how to manage dreams. I hope these ideas help. Be well... Robin J. Landwehr, DBH, LPC, NCC

Sounds as though your son is "pissed off" about something.Punishment will most likely result in more of the same, not less of the peeing you would like to stop from happening."Laziness" is more of a social judgement than it is a characteristic of its own merit.Is this your description of your son or his description of himself?First step always before addressing any of the family dynamics, emotions, and psychology of the people involved, is a medical rule out as to why your son pees at times he plays video games.If he has medical clearance that there is no physiological  problem, then talk with your son on his opinions as to why he pees, if he is aware of the urge to pee and ignores it, or that his attention gets so absorbed he doesn't notice the urge to pee.See what modifications you can create by cooperating with your son.Maybe it is as simple as each two hours, he sets a timer and when it goes off, he takes a bathroom break.

You are very wise for a young person. You have already figured out that other people's behaviours...how they treat you...it's not about you...it's about them. I love that you don't blame yourself for your mom's behaviours. It's not your fault. She's getting upset because she doesn't know how to manage her emotions, and these emotions have to do with her past and her present stress. You're just the trigger. Yes, this is normal, but it's not necessary. She can find another way to manage her "stuff".Unfortunately, you can't help your mom a whole lot or even help her recognize this. But for yourself... remembering that her behaviours are her issue is the biggest piece of "dealing with it". You can always try some new strategies when you talk to mom...you can say "I'll listen you better if you don't bring up past stuff", or "I'm worried about you mom. You seem stressed", or even "I don't like the way you talk to me". Good luck!

It's understandable that your fiancé might feel upset about this situation. From a psychological perspective, it appears that there has been a miscommunication or a lack of transparency in your financial arrangements. His anger might be a result of feeling deceived or betrayed due to both the financial loss and the disagreement about financial responsibilities. It's important for couples to communicate openly and honestly about financial matters to prevent misunderstandings and potential conflicts. In this situation, you might consider discussing the importance of being clear about what each other's responsibilities are in managing your finances. Additionally, you could create a system to ensure that you are both aware of all financial obligations to avoid any future misunderstandings. Keep in mind that open communication and financial transparency are the foundation for healthy financial relationships.

I understand that you have a lot on your plate with your involvement in multiple sports teams, and it can be challenging to balance your commitments with your emotional wellbeing. It's not uncommon to feel obligated to continue with an activity, particularly when there are external pressures, such as your father's expectations. However, if you're experiencing significant anxiety and distress before track meets, it's essential to consider your emotional and physical health. Have you tried speaking with your coach or a trusted teammate about how you're feeling? It might also be helpful to explore some relaxation techniques, such as deep breathing or progressive muscle relaxation, to help manage your anxiety. It's important to recognize that it's okay to prioritize your wellbeing and consider whether continuing with track, especially if it's causing you this much distress, is the best choice for you. You may want to consider exploring this with a mental health professional, who can provide you with additional support and guidance.

It's important to know that there are counselors who are trained in working with survivors of trauma and you can get help.  The "blur" in your memories is your brain's attempt to protect you from the experiences in your past.  To recover them can be a slow process done by a trained professional that you trust.  When you are ready and feel safe, those memories can be recovered and can be integrated with other memories.  This will help to lessen the potency of the memory, help to make sense of what has happened, and allow you to begin the healing process.  Check into therapist who are trained in EMDR (Eye Movement Desensitization and Reprocessing).

It may be important to look at this as getting through something rather than "getting over it." If you're aware of the reasons why you are jealous, I don't know if they relate to this relationship or a previous one, but you could remind yourself of the differences if your feelings of jealousy relate to something from your past.Also, it may be beneficial to have a conversation with your child's father if you are both open to having a discussion about this in a way that you summarize what each other is saying so you are sure that you are understanding each other, at least to some degree.Also, consider what you may want from your child's father to assist you with this. You cannot make him do anything to support you with this, but you can certainly ask.What is something you could start or stop doing to move you toward your goal?

I understand how difficult it can be to deal with feelings of jealousy and insecurity in relationships. It's important to remember that every relationship has its unique dynamics, and it's essential to communicate openly about your concerns with your boyfriend.  First, try to express your feelings in a clear and calm manner, focusing on how you feel rather than accusations or blame. Make sure to listen to his perspective and try to understand his side of the situation.  If his interactions with this female friend do make you uncomfortable, consider setting some boundaries, such as limiting the number of times they interact in person or asking for more transparency about their communication. It's important to remember that trust is built through open and honest interactions.  It might also be helpful to focus on building your own self-confidence and finding other sources of social connection outside of the relationship. In many cases, jealousy and insecurity can stem from a lack of self-worth or self-esteem.  If the situation continues to bother you despite your efforts to communicate and set boundaries, it may be worth speaking with a therapist or counselor to help you work through your feelings and develop healthy coping strategies.

You must be feeling frustrated about how to resolve this. Some people seem to really provoke emotional responses in us. One thing to learn for a quick review of yourself when you are provoked is to pay attention to your body. Notice your heart rate, fists clenched, some warmth going through your body and these are signs that the interaction is toxic for you. Move out of the room, say something calling to both of you and let things simmer down before responding. When you are able to calm your body, think of ways to bring the issue to her attention using positive words but holding your ground. If she doesn't listen ask someone to come with you to talk to her about it, If she still won't listen, reassess your expectations of her.Finally if you need to , you may have to consider changing the status of your rooming together.

I understand your concern for your friend's wellbeing. Major depression is a serious mental health condition, and it can be difficult for someone experiencing it to recognize and accept the diagnosis on their own. The symptoms you've described, such as feeling empty, avoiding social interactions, and only experiencing anger and sadness, are consistent with depression. However, it's important to remember that ultimately, your friend has to make the decision to seek help.  As a friend, you can continue to be supportive by encouraging him to take small steps, such as going for a walk together or engaging in an activity they enjoy. You can also offer to go with him to a doctor's appointment or help him research different treatment options. It may also be helpful to educate him about depression and the benefits of seeking help.  However, it's essential to respect his decision and not force the issue if he's not ready. Mental health treatment is a highly personal and sometimes complex process, and people often need to come to the decision to seek help in their own time and in their own way.  If you're concerned about your friend's safety, you should consider reaching out to a mental health professional or crisis hotline for guidance. They can provide you with resources and support in navigating this situation.

I'm sorry to hear that you've had to take this step to protect yourself from your ex-fiancé. The physical sensations you're experiencing, such as feeling sick when you stand up, could be your body's way of reacting to the emotional stress and trauma you've experienced. This response is not uncommon, and it's a normal part of your body's fight or flight response. It's important that you prioritize self-care in the coming days, including getting enough rest, eating well, and finding activities that help you relax and feel safe. Additionally, it may be helpful for you to connect with a therapist or support group to process your emotions and work through the stress of the situation. Remember, you have taken an important step for your well-being and it's important to prioritize your health during this time.

Hi Tampa, I get that this is a loss for all of you; you have bonded with this child as a result of the significant time you have spent with him. He's a lucky boy to have had you all taking care of him. Certainly, it seems that his mother might not be making the best decision for her son; if you are willing to maintain the relationship, it would be good for him to still have that contact. In my book, the more people loving a child, the better. But, ultimately, she has the right to make these decisions. To oppose her won't likely do any good. You can focus on grieving this relationship and supporting your brother through his loss as well.

I understand that you're feeling lonely and lacking intimacy in your marriage due to your wife's long work hours and your own connections at work. It's natural to miss the closeness and emotional and physical connection you once shared. The absence of sexual intimacy can be particularly troubling.  First, I would encourage you to communicate openly and honestly with your wife about your feelings and concerns. She may not be aware of how much her work schedule is affecting you. It's important to remember that many factors can influence a couple's sex life, and it's often a good idea to address any underlying issues before focusing solely on the sexual aspect.  If you're both open to discussing this, you might consider finding ways to prioritize your relationship and spend more quality time together. This could include planning regular date nights, setting aside time for meaningful conversation, or even exploring new hobbies or activities together.  It's also crucial to address any underlying emotional or relational issues that may be contributing to your feelings of loneliness and disconnection. Sometimes, sexual difficulties can be a symptom of deeper emotional issues, and addressing the root cause can help improve your intimacy and closeness as a couple.  Your bond with your coworker doesn't necessarily have to be a concern if it remains professional and platonic. However, it's essential to ensure that it doesn't cross any boundaries or make you feel like you're emotionally or emotionally investing too much in the relationship.  Remember, it's essential to take care of your emotional and relational needs, and open communication with your partner can be a crucial step in rebuilding and strengthening your bond. Additionally, considering seeking professional help, such as couples therapy or guidance from a mental health professional, if your relationship struggles persist.

Many people generate intense anxiety with obsessive thinking.  While the nature of your obsession about the afterlife and eternity appear very powerful and unique to you, the pattern of obsessing about one thing/area is common.  I suggest that you consider counseling to help you with your anxiety.  If you are so inclined, there are also medications which may bring relief.  Obviously, I can't diagnose you from one paragraph, so it would be wise to visit an experienced mental health professional (either a counselor or an MD in your area) to help you with disengaging from your self-destructive thoughts.  CBT, Cognitive Behavioral Therapy, is a very effective counseling approach for obsessive thinking.  If you'd like a see a top notch CBT therapist, visit www.AcademyofCT.org.  And of course I suggest you pick up my book, LIVING YES, A HANDBOOK FOR BEING HUMAN, which includes CBT concepts and many more tools which will help with obsession and anxiety.As for believing yourself "insane" (or "crazy") this is not a mental health term but a legal one (or a slang).  So as long as you don't commit a crime, no professional can legitimately call you insane or crazy!Take it slow!  ~Mark (www.MarkMorrisLCSW.com and www.LivingYes.org)

It's important to understand that the value of a person is not determined by their physical appearance. Your friends most likely value and appreciate you for who you are, not just for how you look. You mentioned that you've been wearing a bra that's too big to give the illusion of larger breasts around your peers, but this behavior may be causing you distress when it comes to inviting friends over to your house.  Let's explore some coping strategies together. One idea would be to focus on the many aspects of your personality and the talents you possess that make you unique. If you're feeling insecure about your appearance, try practicing self-acceptance. This can involve setting positive self-statements, focusing on your inner values, and practicing self-care routines. Additionally, consider addressing any underlying feelings of inadequacy that may be contributing to this behavior. It may be helpful to seek support from a therapist who can assist you in working through these emotions and building your self-worth. Remember, it's normal for young people to feel self-conscious at times, and it's an opportunity to learn and grow.

That sounds really challenging for both of you. Differences in sexual desire between partners is common and can create real friction and conflict. I would encourage you to do some couples counselling or sex therapy as often these issues can be worked through and low sexual desire can result from relational fears and misunderstandings or sex that isn't as arousing as is possible. There are some good videos on this resource page about sexuality and intimacy and a video that specifically addresses desire differences in relationships.

That sounds awful, and is clearly unsustainable.  There are some great answers that give some guidance about what might be an underlying condition.  If all physical and mental health issues are ruled out, it's time to take action.  Get backup from friends or family members if you need to, but let your daughter know you are giving her 30 days notice.  She needs to find another place to live within that time.  If she wants to stay with you, be clear that first she has to go, with a potential to return after she has been out for a good chunk of time.  Once out, she can prove to you, and more importantly to herself, that she is capable of maintaining her health and her environment.  Remember, you are going to rule out issues that would make it impossible for her to be successful; if she is in good health, her staying with you and living this way is actually harming her.

I'm glad you recognize your own best interest and that your life will be much better without verbal and emotional abuse.One of the terrible results of being abused in a relationship which is expected to be loving, safe and supportive, is that the one who is being abused, starts to question their own judgement, rights, opinions, overall way of thinking.This happens because partners who are intimately involved with one another are very meaningful.  Regardless of how irrational, wrong, mean, selfish, intimidating, thoughtless, a partner is to the other, the person on the receiving side gradually starts questioning whether they are wrong for not accepting these sorts of interactions.Stick with what your own intuition tells you.There is a part within each of us which knows the truth of what is going on.Leaving a relationship is always difficult to some degree.  People are in familiar patterns of daily behavior, no one wants to suddenly "be alone", even if this only means showing up as a physical body, not as a truly loving partner, no one wants to start telling others about a breakup, answer questions about it, feel blamed, worry what others think.These are secondary matters to following the truth in your own heart.Listen to yourself about leaving this guy. Your inner self does not lie to you.

I'm sorry to hear that you're going through this painful experience, but I cannot provide you with exact advice without complete understanding of your unique situation. However, I can say that when someone's words do not align with their actions, it can be a sign of confusion or a lack of commitment in a relationship. Your feelings of love and pain are valid, and recognizing them can help you make decisions about your future. Consider seeking the guidance of a mental health professional, such as a therapist, who can help you navigate these complex emotions and provide you with tools and strategies to move forward. Remember, investing time and energy into a relationship should be a mutual and equal effort. If that balance is not there, it may be time to reconsider your involvement.

Sometimes repressing anger can lead to depression and block all kinds of other emotions too.  I would wonder about your experience with anger and if you've ever been discouraged from expressing anger.  I would also wonder if you feel like you have space to express yourself in your relationship or if you feel like you really aren't being heard.  It's hard to feel cared for and connected to someone else when you don't feel accepted by them.

It sounds like you would like to let other people get close to you and at the same time you are finding yourself compelled to keep people at a distance. Often times, when we have difficulty trusting others, it is because we have specific fears about what would happen if we get close or let our guard down. Such fears may be rooted in past experiences in relationships in which we were hurt and or disappointed. In working with a therapist, you can gain insight into what is underneath your compulsion to put walls around yourself and develop ways to form authentic, lasting, satisfying relationships with others.

I understand how hurtful it can be to be labeled with names that are not true to who you are. The first step to take is to practice self-compassion and focus on your own values and actions, rather than getting caught up in what others say or do. It's important to remember that people's words and actions are often a reflection of their own insecurities or issues, rather than a true reflection of who you are. If the situation permits, consider having an open and respectful conversation about how the name-calling is affecting you, and ask them to refrain from using such language. If the situation continues to be harmful, it may be helpful to seek support from friends, family, or a mental health professional.

It's important to remember that I can't make a definitive diagnosis from just one interaction, but I can offer some potential explanations based on the information provided. It's possible that your partner is engaging in a behavior known as soliloquy – talking to himself, often out loud, as a way to process thoughts or emotions. This can be a normal and healthy behavior in some cases.  However, if this behavior is causing you distress, it might be worth exploring in more depth. It's also possible that there may be underling issues at play, such as dementia, mental health conditions, or substance abuse. I would recommend considering reaching out to a mental health professional for further evaluation and support. They can help you navigate this situation and provide guidance on how to best address any underlying concerns.  Additionally, it's important to approach this situation with empathy and open communication. Instead of accusing or making assumptions, try having an honest conversation with your partner about how his behavior is affecting you. Express your concerns in a non-confrontational way and be open to hearing his perspective. This could lead to a better understanding and resolution for both of you.

I understand this is a difficult situation for you, and it's essential to process the emotions and events surrounding your husband's emotional affair. Based on what you've shared, it appears that your husband acted in a deceptive and dishonest manner. The fact that he initially lied to you about his whereabouts and then later disclosed that he stayed with his ex-wife, even when he knew you were aware, indicates a breach of trust.  Regarding your specific question, infidelity often involves physical intimacy, but it's important to remember that emotional intimacy can also be damaging to a relationship, especially when it's hidden from a partner. Based on your husband's account, it does seem that they slept in the same bed, which could indicate physical intimacy, albeit not necessarily sexual. However, it's essential to note that even without that explicit detail, the emotional connection and manipulation surrounding the affair could be harmful to your relationship.  Given this context, it may be helpful for you and your husband to address the underlying issues that led to his emotional affair, such as communication, trust, and potential unresolved feelings or needs. Counseling could be a useful tool to help you and your husband explore these issues and work towards restoring trust and rebuilding your relationship. It's crucial to remember that healing from infidelity is a process, and it can take time, effort, and dedication from both partners to create a strong and secure bond once more.

I'm sorry to hear that you're going through a difficult time after the break-up with your fiancé. It's important to acknowledge the pain you're feeling and the sense of betrayal as a result of his infidelity. You mentioned that you forgave him but also found yourself questioning his every move, which can be exhausting and unhealthy for both partners in a relationship.  It's crucial to remember that trust is the foundation of any healthy and long-lasting relationship. When trust is broken repeatedly, it can be challenging to rebuild and maintain that trust. In your situation, it seems that despite your efforts to move past the infidelity, the constant questioning and doubt took a toll on your partner and ultimately led to the end of your relationship.  Moving forward, it's essential to focus on healing, learning from your experiences, and cultivating self-love and self-worth. Reflecting on what you want and need in a partner and a relationship will help you make informed decisions in the future.  It's normal to feel hurt and confused, and processing these emotions can be helpful to your overall healing. I would recommend exploring those feelings further with a trusted friend or a therapist to gain a better understanding of yourself and what you need in a relationship.  Remember, taking the time for self-care and self-improvement are essential steps in the healing process. I wish you all the best as you embark on this journey towards healing and growth. It won't be an easy process, but with patience, compassion, and a strong support system, you'll come out stronger on the other side.

It is possible that you could have or be developing an anxiety disorder. There isn't really enough information provided here to suggest a particular disorder, but it might be worth meeting with a counselor or therapist to do a formal assessment. Some of the questions they might ask could be what other kinds of physical symptoms you experience, how frequently these physical symptoms happen, what's going on for you when they tend to happen, and how frequently/intensely you find yourself worrying in general. Anxiety itself is a really natural thing - it's just when it starts interfering with your ability to "do life" the way you want that we start to consider potential disorders. It might be that for the most part, the anxiety you feel is normal and you simply have some triggers that intensify it more than usual. Working on your own or with the support of a counselor/therapist to both address those triggers at the root and also to develop ways of managing the actual anxiety symptoms. This two-fold approach can be really helpful for not letting anxiety keep you from engaging in life the way you'd like.

Your partner loves you but must have fear that keeps standing in his way. It could also mean their afraid of getting hurt or disapointed in the long run. Your feelings are valid, and it's normal to consider reaching out to someone from your past. However, factors such as timing and intentions are essential to consider. Based on the information you've given me, it doesn't seem like there are any pressing reasons to contact him right away. If you genuinely want to reconnect as friends, you could consider sending a friendly message. However, if you have romantic intentions, it's essential to be honest and clear about them, as miscommunication can lead to unnecessary discomfort. Remember, there's no one-size-fits-all solution, so it's vital to consider the potential outcomes and your own emotional well-being before taking any action.

Absolutely, social anxiety is treatable. One effective approach is cognitive-behavioral therapy (CBT), which involves learning skills to manage your thoughts, emotions, and behaviors in anxious-provoking situations. Another option is exposure therapy, where you gradually expose yourself to the social situations that cause your anxiety. Medication, such as antidepressants or anti-anxiety drugs, may also be helpful for some people. It's important to remember that overcoming social anxiety takes time and effort. It may be helpful for you to work with a mental health professional, who can provide you with tools and support to help you progress. Additionally, practicing relaxation techniques, such as deep breathing or progressive muscle relaxation, can help you feel more calm and centered before entering social situations.

I’m sorry to hear about your current situation. My heart goes out to you during this time.First of all, it is of vital importance that you discuss your symptoms with your doctor. Regardless of whether you are able to mend your relationship with your husband, you need to address the physical issues you are experiencing. More than likely he/she will be able to help you relieve some of these symptoms.Secondly, you must be upfront and honest with your husband. Intimacy is a large part of a relationship and it is unfair to your husband that you did not disclose how you were feeling. I think he would appreciate knowing that it was your medical problems causing the lack of sexual desire as opposed to the reason being him.If you explain to him that you are addressing your sexual issues with your doctor in order to enhance your relationship, he may be more willing to see that you are serious in wanting to mend the relationship. The conversation will be hard to explain to your doctor and your husband since it is of such a personal nature but it will be extremely beneficial. And please note that the reason for the feelings you were experiencing (or lack thereof), was not your fault.Best of luck to you and your husband!

You are right on to recognize that the effects of trauma can be cumulative. New York, what would it mean about you if you got her back? Is that the only way you can like or forgive yourself...if she forgives you and takes you back?
